ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

VACANT HUDC FLATS


    1. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development how many HUDC flats were vacant as at 31st January, 1987 and what he proposes to do with them.

    The Minister for National Development (Mr S.Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, as at 31st January 1987, there were 1,099 unsold HUDC flats. These vacant flats have arisen because the HDB built them in response to demands by HUDC applicants. When large numbers of applicants subsequently withdrew their applications, the Board had already committed itself to building the flats. The completion of these flats has resulted in the present vacancy rate.

    The HDB has stopped building new HUDC flats. The present plan is to sell the existing stock to new applicants as well as to those on the waiting list for HUDC flats until the stock has exhausted. I have asked HDB to also study other ways of accelerating sales without disrupting the market.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, would the Hon. Minister consider lifting the income ceiling as one of the ways to accelerate sales?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, this is of course one of the ways to encourage sale of HUDC flats. I am not sure at the present moment how disruptive it would be on the private sector market. But I have already asked HDB to be a little more flexible in the application of the income ceiling.

Column: 127

HDB HOME OWNERSHIP SCHEME
(Waiver of deposit)


    2. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for National Development whether the Housing and Development Board will consider waiving the deposit required under the home ownership scheme, particularly for those living in one-room and two-room rental flats who wish to upgrade themselves.

Column: 128



     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, buying a house or flat requires a long term financial commitment and the purchaser should show some ability to plan his expenditure before taking on such a commitment. A downpayment should therefore be made. The HDB recognizes that certain categories of applicants, particularly those living in 1-room and 2-room rental flats who wish to upgrade themselves, may not be able to afford the usual initial downpayment of 20%. Therefore, they need only pay 5% downpayment to purchase a 4-room Simplified flat or a smaller flat and 10% downpayment if they want to buy a 4-room Model A flat or a bigger flat. These concessions are applicable to the following groups of people:

    (a) Tenants of rental flats;

    (b) Applicants in the HDB Rental Waiting List;

    (c) Applicants in the Sales Waiting List whose current gross household incomes do not exceed $800 per month.

    In view of this concession, the HDB will not totally waive the deposit required under the Home Ownership Scheme, except for tenants who are affected by redevelopment. Those who are affected by redevelopment do not have to make a downpayment.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Bo Wen): Sir, would not waiving the deposit help to reduce the problem of over supply of flats that we face at the moment and at the same time help to upgrade the social conditions of these people who are living in 1- and 2-room flats?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, yes, we would like to encourage as many as possible to buy these flats. But we should not encourage people who are not able to plan their finances to buy these flats because, having bought the flats, they then may have difficulty in financing their monthly instalment payments. That is why we have decided that at least a minimum of 5% or 10%, as I have described, should be required. The downpayment is not hefty for a 3-room or 4-room Simplified flat, say, in the new towns. The downpayment would be about $1,700 for a 3-room flat and $2,100 for a 4-S flat; that is working on 5%. It is really not very much.

Column: 129

And this, of course, can be paid out of the CPF in the case of people who do have CPF balances. In addition to these downpayment concessions, there are other concessions on the monthly instalment payment to enable such people to afford the purchase of these flats. At the present moment, we are satisfied that these concessions are sufficient to enable most of the people who are renting flats and most of those who earn less than $800 per month to afford HDB flats.

The Ministry of Finance issued a press statement on the report in June 1986 which listed the acceptance by the Government of several significant recommendations of the Committee. This press statement (Cols. 227 - 230) has been circulated to Members for easy reference.

JUNIOR COLLEGE IN UPPER SERANGOON
(Construction)


    4. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Education whether the land earmarked for the construction of a junior college in the vicinity of Upper Serangoon Road and Lim Ah Pin Road will be used for some other purposes; and, if not, when construction work will commence.

     The Minister of State for Education (Dr Tay Eng Soon) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am replying on behalf of my Minister.

    A junior college will be built at the site in question. The consultant architect for the project has advised that piling work is expected to commence in September this year.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: May I ask the Hon. Minister of State for Education why there has been such a long delay in the construction of a junior college at this site?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the three junior colleges that are being planned for construction beginning sometime this year or early next year were chosen as a result of a competition among architects for the design of junior colleges. In an open competition of that nature, time has to be spent by firms as well as by judges to make sure that the best design is selected.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, must it take two years or so for such a decision to be made?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: All I can say is that the whole process took some time because it involved a lot of parties, including the Singapore Institute of Architects, the PWD and others.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, how long will it take to complete this college?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Going by past records, the construction time of a junior college is about three to four years.

Column: 131

QUALIFIED TEACHERS AND UNTRAINED RELIEF TEACHERS


    5. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for Education (a) what was the number of untrained relief teachers employed as at the latest convenient date; and (b) what steps are being taken to ensure that there are sufficient qualified teachers available besides the supply from the Institute of Education.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, the number of untrained relief teachers as at January this year was 594, or between one and two relief teachers per school.

    Our main shortage today is for teachers able to teach English, the Humanities, and Physical Education in secondary schools. Besides the Institute of Education, which is the main source of trained teachers for the Ministry, Physical Education teachers are trained at the College of Physical Education. This year 54 graduates from the College of Physical Education are expected to join the Education Service. Serving non-graduate teachers are encouraged to upgrade themselves through the Ministry's bursary schemes and through the grant of study leave to further their studies in degree courses relevant to the Ministry's needs. In 1986 about 60 serving teachers were given leave or bursaries to further their studies. Where necessary, the Ministry will also continue to recruit expatriate native speakers to teach English in our schools and junior colleges and to help in teaching specialized areas, for example, the Humanities Programme, the Art Elective Programme and the teaching of foreign languages.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): How many expatriate teachers are there now employed by the Government in our schools?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: I do not have the exact figure with me, Sir, but the figure is around 150.

     Mr Sia Khoon Seong (Moulmein): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Minister of State for Education whether this dependency on relief teachers will become worse, now that the Ministry of Finance has announced that very generous leave

Column: 132

could be allowed for female officers in view of its present drive on procreation?

    Is it not true that there are some 18,000 teachers in the Education Service today? And is it also not true that out of these 18,000 teachers about 60% are females? If that is the case, there would be about 10,000 female teachers. Now, assuming that out of these 10,000 female teachers, 30% are within the fertile age and that only one-third take advantage of this scheme, will not the problem of dependency on relief teachers be worsened by two-fold? So if the figure, as quoted by the Minister of State ---

     Mr Speaker: Mr Sia, you are very long-winded in asking supplementary questions.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: I thank the Member for Moulmein for his question. We do not know what the impact of this new policy will be. We believe that if more women teachers become pregnant and have to take leave, more temporary vacancies may be created and therefore we have to recruit more relief teachers. If that does happen, I think it is in a sense a cause for rejoicing because this is something which we as a nation would like to see.

    On the other hand, even today under present circumstances, we do have many teachers going on maternity leave and there will always be a need for relief teachers to cover these temporary vacancies. I believe we are able to cope with an exigency of that kind.

     Mr Sia Khoon Seong: Mr Speaker, Sir, could I ask the Minister of State whether dependency on relief teachers would not negate all the efforts of the Ministry of Education towards excellence in schools? The problem, as it is, is bad enough. So ---

     Mr Speaker: Mr Sia, would you allow the Minister to reply first?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: The Ministry intends to increase the intake for the Institute of Education. This has to be done progressively as we find more candidates who have the right qualities and qualifications to become teachers. But we are committed to increasing the intake for the Institute of Education and, in the course of time, the numbers of relief teachers will diminish.

INDEPENDENT AND NON-INDEPENDENT SCHOOLS


    6. Mr Chiam See Tong asked the Minister for Education what will be the ratio of Government recurrent expenditure per year on each pupil in an independent school to that of a pupil in a Government non-independent school.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, this question is premature as the implementation plan for independent schools has not yet been finalized. One possibility that is being considered is for Government to give a grant for each pupil studying in an independent school equivalent to the recurrent expenditure expended by the Government on a pupil in a Government school today.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: I am asking for the ratio of recurrent expenditure. I did not hear the answer.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Mr Speaker, Sir, I thought I have already given the answer.

ADMINISTRATION OF JURONG PORT


    7. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for Communications and Information whether his Ministry intends to take over the administration of Jurong Port so as to standardise port administration in Singapore.

     The Minister for Communications and Information (Dr Yeo Ning Hong): Sir, Jurong Port was established in 1965 to serve the factories in the Jurong Industrial Estate. It is owned by the Jurong Town Corporation (JTC) but managed by PSA in accordance with the management agreement between PSA and JTC. This arrangement has ensured proper coordination and standardized port administration and tariff structure.

    There might be advantages in pooling the resources of all the gateways in Singapore to optimize the use of our facilities and to further increase the levels of efficiency. This could further improve our competitive edge. My Ministry and the Ministry of Trade and Industry will study the merits of bringing Jurong Port under the administration of PSA.

Column: 134



     Mr Yeo Choo Kok (Delta): Sir, when does the Ministry intend to study the pros and cons of this proposal and when will it be completed? How long will it take?

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, studies have already been initiated and they will be carried out as expeditiously as possible.

Column: 134

SINGAPORE MARITIME POSITION
(Maintenance of)


    8. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for Communications and Information what steps his Ministry will take to ensure that Singapore maintains its maritime competitive edge.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, the maritime industry covers a wide range of activities, from ship-owning, ship-management, port services and other shipping and port related activities.

    As regards port services, from October 1984 up to December 1986, PSA has granted several concessions on tariffs amounting to about $150 million. These concessions have resulted in a saving for ships that call at our ports, eg, savings of up to 22% in port costs for the latest third generation container ships and savings of up to 32% for a feeder vessel. These concessions have helped to maintain Singapore's competitive edge as a major transhipment port. The results speak for themselves. In 1986, cargo handled at the port increased by 14% to 121 million tonnes. Shipping tonnage which is the tonnage of ships that call at Singapore also increased in 1986 by 23% to 325 million gross registered tonnes. This tonnage is expected to make Singapore the world's busiest port for the year 1986.

    Ships and cargoes are attracted to Singapore because of the high level of service and productivity of our port. It is this high productivity that has given us the competitive edge. To ensure that we maintain this competitive edge, additional port facilities will be built and cargo handling equipment will be added to cater for expected growth in shipping tonnage and cargo. PSA expects to spend about $1.2 billion over the next five years. With

Column: 135

higher productivity, the resultant savings can then be passed on to port users, thus lowering their cost of operations in Singapore.

    With regard to ship-owning and ship-management, I understand that the Singapore National Shipping Association is presently studying a report by its consultants on the promotion of Singapore as an international centre for ship -owning and ship-management services. The recommendations of the Association will certainly be given serious consideration by the relevant Government authorities.

Column: 135

EXTENSION OF MRT TO CHANGI AIRPORT


    9. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the Minister for Communications and Information whether the Mass Rapid Transit system will be extended to Changi Airport in view of the construction of Passenger Terminal II and, if not, why.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Mr Speaker, Sir, studies have been undertaken by consultants to evaluate the feasibility of extending the MRT line to Changi Airport. These studies have concluded that a branch line to Changi Airport will not be viable, even with the construction of Passenger Terminal II.

    When Changi and the areas around the Airport are fully developed in the future and more traffic builds up, we will review the plans again. When the demand can justify the extension of the MRT to Changi Airport, the MRTC will construct it.

EMPLOYMENT OF GURKHA MERCENARIES


    10. Mr Chiam See Tong asked the Minister for Home Affairs why is there the necessity to employ mercenaries like the Gurkhas to guard key areas in Singapore when we are already spending so much money on national defence.

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Mr Speaker, Sir, first, may I have clarification from the Member for Potong Pasir. Since his question refers to provision for expenditure on national defence, do I take it that the question

Column: 136

he is asking really is: why provisions for national defence include provision for Gurkhas, and why is it that Gurkhas form part of our Armed Forces? Can I take it that that is his question?

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Perhaps the Minister could clarify exactly what the Gurkhas are here for and in what capacity. And then I will answer that question.

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, if the Member for Potong Pasir looks at the provisions in the Budget, it will be clear to him that National Defence has got no provision for Gurkhas. And the Gurkhas are here not as part of the Armed Forces but as members of the Police Force for purposes of internal security and law and order.

    Sir, there are two reasons why we have Gurkhas in Singapore. The first reason is that they have a well-established reputation for toughness, alertness, mental and physical resilience in adversity and for total dependability, self-discipline, utter loyalty and fearlessness in the execution of their duties. They obey their orders to the end and do not deviate from instructions given to them. These qualities have stood the test of time and have won them world -wide acclaim.

    The Gurkhas have been in Singapore since 1949. Our experience is that secret society gangsters and all other criminals in Singapore have a healthy respect for the Gurkhas. They are not only known to be tough and fearless in enforcing the law but, because they are not part of Singaporean society, they are not so vulnerable to intimidation, influence and corruption.

    The second reason is that they have a record for complete impartiality when serving in a multi-racial society. This is especially valuable in any communal situation where tensions may be high and violence can flare up. A Gurkha will obey orders and keep the peace regardless of which racial group is causing the trouble. All racial groups know that the Gurkhas will brook no nonsense from anyone and will side with no one in establishing peace and order. Their effectiveness in performing this role has been proven in the racial riots of the 1950s and the 1960s.

Column: 137



    Sir, the Gurkhas are thus neutral and impartial implementors of the law and are regarded as such. In the event of any communal tension, their very presence would have both a deterrent as well as a calming and reassuring effect on all racial groups.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, we have heard all the good qualities of the Gurkhas' toughness, resilience, impartiality, loyalty and a whole list of other good points. Is the Minister saying that our own citizens are lacking in all these qualities?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, both as a Singaporean and as a member of the Government, I am very proud of our own Police Force and have absolute confidence in them. And I think we all can have confidence in them. The question really is: when we have had, since the 1940s, the presence in Singapore of the world's toughest and best fighters as part of our law enforcement team, do we now pack them off, or should we keep them here for the reasons that I have given, to augment our Police Force? I think the answer is obvious. It is in our interest to keep them for so long as we can get them and for so long as they are prepared to be here.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: In 1940-49, that was the period when we were under the British.

     Mr Speaker: Mr Chiam, it is no use repeating history. Ask your supplementary question, please.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Mr Minister, we are now an independent country. Is it really necessary to employ mercenaries in place of our own citizens? Is that not a smack on the face of our own citizens? They have all these qualities. You say you have confidence in the Police Force. Why do you not let them take over the job of the Gurkhas?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have already given the reasons for the presence of the Gurkhas. Whether we are independent or not is irrelevant. There are other independent countries which also employ Gurkhas, both developing and developed countries. As to whether this reflects on

Column: 138

the confidence of the Police, let me say that I have posed the question to my Commissioner of Police. I have asked him that, as a professional police officer and as the Commissioner of Police, what was his response to the question Mr Chiam had posed, and which I had anticipated. His view was categoric. He said to me that he would not recommend the dismantling of the Gurkha Contingent now or in the near future. As to whether their presence in Singapore affects the confidence or the morale of the Police, again his answer was categorically no. The morale of the Police Force is in no way affected because they are here for special reasons and everyone knows it.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, may I ask the Minister what are the key areas that are guarded by the Gurkhas in Singapore?

     Prof. Jayakumar: He wants to know the key areas. Mr Speaker, Sir, I think it is both foolhardy and dangerous for me, as the Minister in charge of security, to openly divulge and discuss the security and protective measures which I have put in place for both local and foreign VIPs and vital installations in Singapore. We will be only playing into the hands of trouble makers, crackpots, saboteurs, arsonists and assassins.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Last question, Sir. Is the residence of the Prime Minister guarded by Gurkhas?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Is it true that the Gurkhas are guarding the Prime Minister's residence? It is true. Is it true that they are the only ones who are guarding the Prime Minister's residence? The answer is no. And beyond that, I think it will be stupid for any Member of the House to ask me more details of any of the other protective and security measures.

OVERTIME PAY
(Exemption from CPF)


    11. Mr Chiam See Tong asked the Minister for Labour whether he will exempt Central Provident Fund contributions on overtime pay.

     The Minister for Labour (Mr Lee Yock Suan): Mr Speaker, Sir, payment for over-

Column: 139

time work will not be exempted from Central Provident Fund contributions. Workers who are required to work overtime should be paid the full benefits that they are entitled to, including CPF. As CPF contributions form part of workers' wages, exempting overtime pay from employers' CPF contributions would tantamount to cutting the workers' wages. As it is, the employer's CPF contribution rate has already been cut from 25% to 10% to reduce wage cost.

    Some workers may prefer a lower employee's CPF contribution rate for overtime pay or, for that matter, all categories of pay. The question here is what the total CPF rate should be to meet the basic objectives of the CPF Scheme. Exempting overtime pay from CPF contributions would require the contribution rate for basic pay to be raised to compensate for the reduction. This could lead to distortion of the labour market and the way work is structured. It is therefore better to apply the same rate of CPF contribution to all categories of pay. Administratively, it would also be very difficult for the CPF Board to differentiate between the various categories of pay to apply different rates of CPF contribution.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, would not the Minister agree with me that one of the problems of Singapore's economy was the high wage costs? So in not allowing this exemption of CPF from overtime pay, would it not be against that policy?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: The question of the high wage cost has already been addressed last year when the cut was made in the employer's CPF contribution rate from 25% to 10%. I think that is sufficient and the experience over the last 12 months or so and the economic recovery since then bear out the adequacy of the measures taken. So there is no need for us to go further and cut the workers' pay. Is the Member for Potong Pasir so keen that we should constantly cut into workers' wages?

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Mr Minister, it is for you to answer the question. It is not for me. My duty is to ask questions. Would the Minister agree with me that, in fact, if there is no exemption of Central Provident

Column: 140

Fund from overtime pay, it would hurt our local businessmen more than the multi-nationals?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: The same overtime rate of pay is applicable to all the employers, ie the employer has to pay 50% over the normal pay for overtime work. Normally when companies require their workers to work overtime, it means they have good business. There are orders to be filled. So in general there is really no need for us to give further incentives either to the employers or to the employees for overtime work.

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon (Yuhua): Question No. 12, please.

     Mr Lim Boon Heng (Kebun Baru): Would the Minister not agree ---

     Mr Speaker: Question No. 12 has been asked.

COMPANIES IN ARREARS OF CPF CONTRIBUTIONS
(Figures)


    12. Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon asked the Minister for Labour (a) what were the number and percentage of companies in Singapore which were often in arrears in Central Provident Fund contributions as at the latest convenient date; (b) what was the number of companies under receivership in 1986 which did not pay up their CPF contributions; and (c) to date, what is the highest amount owed to the CPF Board by any one company in Singapore.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Speaker, during the second half of 1986, 3,916 employers were habitually late in making their CPF contributions, ie they were late in making their contributions for three or more months. This number constitutes about 6% of the total number of employers making CPF contributions.

    31 companies which came under receivership in 1986 were in arrears in their CPF contributions. The CPF Board has filed claims with the Receivers and Managers for the arrears and is awaiting payment from them.

    To date, the highest amount of contributions owed to the CPF Board by an existing

Column: 141

company is $803,940. This amount is owed by Southern Ocean Shipbuilding Pte. Ltd. The company has repeatedly been in arrears since June 1984. Action by the Board has led to the recovery of some $2.7 million in arrears and penalty interest. The Board has subsequently taken up winding-up action against the company to recover the rest of the contributions. Under court order, the creditors of the company have met and most of them have agreed to an arrangement for the settlement of debts proposed by the company. When the Minister for Labour proposed the original concept of the topping-up scheme, the idea was to transfer savings from one's CPF account to the parent's CPF account. Alternatively, cash can be used to top-up one's parents' CPF account. However, since the end-result is the same, for all intents and purposes, one can view the topping-up cash as additional cash contributions into one's own CPF account which is then transferred to the parents' account. For the self-employed, similar tax relief for cash contribution into his own account is also provided. In the latter case, the contribution is entirely voluntary. This policy of granting tax relief for additional cash contributions is a new one. It introduces a new concept which I would term "tax-free voluntary contribution into the CPF".

    The question that begs to be asked is this: can individuals, other than the self-employed, contribute additional cash under this tax-free scheme into their own CPF accounts? At first glance, one might wonder why on earth would anyone want to do so in the first place, and then why should Government even consider such a proposal since significant tax revenue might be lost if a significant number of people go for this scheme? Column: 219

period of unemployment, then I would say the proposal would start to make some sense. Early withdrawal would also remove the current rigidity of the CPF scheme to allow the individual greater latitude to manage his own money and his own life.     Let me review the basic premises of the CPF scheme briefly. In the beginning, CPF was meant to be savings for old age and, as an incentive, contributions into CPF, which are really deferred income, have been exempted from income tax. Tax exemption makes good sense since CPF money can only be withdrawn after the retirement age at 55 years. The use of CPF contribution for consumption of any kind prior to 55 years has always been denied. However, through the years, Government has allowed the use of CPF money for the purchase of homes, investment in stocks and gold and Medisave accounts have been established. The Minister for Labour has stated in Parliament that the use of CPF account for homes actually entails an element of consumption in it since interest payment is a drawdown of the CPF contributions, particularly during the years of soft property markets.

I would say that, in both the home-ownership scheme and the Medisave scheme, the concept of early withdrawal of CPF money for current consumption has been established. Thus, the notion that no early withdrawal of CPF money for consumption has been breached. More importantly, I would say that the concept of tax-exempted money for retirement has already been changed. In effect, through these two schemes, the State has subsidized CPF contributors by providing tax-free monies for consumption which, if not for the CPF scheme, would have been taxed.

    This can be illustrated very clearly. For instance, if Government were to decide to reduce the employees' CPF contribution rate, the additional take-home pay would

then have been taxed at the employee's current tax rate. Therefore, I would conclude that the Government has already allowed early withdrawal of CPF money for current consumption under very specific circumstances. They are in a situation of having their retirement well taken care of but in the meantime they and their families are living as paupers. While the number of such cases may not be very high, the sufferings of these families going through such rough and trying periods are nonetheless very real. Withdrawal of CPF money to tide them over such things would have been most useful.

Let us see what is the Minimum Sum. The Minimum Sum, I would define it as a sum of money which the Government has deemed sufficient for retired people to live on in their retirement albeit on a mere subsistence level. Under the current policies, as long as there is this minimum sum in cash or in kind in their CPF account, the individual is at liberty to do what he wants or what he likes with the rest of the money so long as he is older than 55 years, ie, past the age of withdrawal of CPF monies.

    I would say that it is quite obvious that the magic number of 55 as the retirement age is losing its significance as people today are healthier and also live longer. So really for people who are younger and who have more than the minimum sum in their CPF account, there is no strong reason why they, when in dire need, cannot make use of their CPF so long as they

Column: 221

are utilizing money in excess of the minimum sum. Also, to allow greater flexibility in the CPF scheme is good. Through this, Government's interference in how people run their lives would be reduced and individuals would be vested with more responsibility in managing their own money. The only problem I can see is that CPF money is tax-free.

    To ensure that people would manage their money judiciously, I propose that the concept of tax deferment, rather than tax exemption, for CPF contribution be examined, ie, when the employee puts his money into the CPF account, the contribution is not tax exempted, as it is now, but tax on it will be deferred till the time it is withdrawn. Of course, if the money is withdrawn after age 55, the money would continue to enjoy the benefit of tax exemption. However, if the money is withdrawn before age 55, the money would be considered as income in the year it is withdrawn and subjected to tax. In other words, it is deferred income. The tax payable would then be computed on the total income for that year. Since this money withdrawn will be taxed, I believe we can count on most people, who need to withdraw from CPF, to be very careful about using such money. These could include hardship for being out of job for a certain period of time and beyond, or for the younger people to stop work in order to go for further studies either locally or overseas.

Secondly, a tax-deferred scheme to allow for early withdrawal of the money in excess of minimum sum under specific circumstances. Thus, the tax can be used as a regulatory mechanism to regulate early withdrawal.

Column: 222
